reviewText:
Early Access Review

Jurassic Island: A Dinosaur Zoo is currently in the Steam Early Access program and it's a tycoon style sim game where you must build and maintain your very own dinosaur theme park (Jurassic World anyone?). It currently has an IndieGoGo campaign going, which has nine days left. Doesn't seem like it's gonna get there.

https://youtu.be/RhIfLolVQUk

First thing I want to point out is that this is another mobile port of a game to hit the Steam Early Access landscape. Not that this is a bad thing, but Jurassic Island does exist on mobile platforms for 99c, which when compared to the $5.99 price tag on Steam can be a bit hard to justify the price increase. Also consider that I haven't played the mobile version, so where a game like Minimon is trying to separate itself from its mobile counterpart, I'm not quite sure what the differences, if any, are.

It also seems the developer has made other games using this format of top town sim with a pair of games, The Terminal and The Terminal 2. So in essence this may just be a reskinned version of those games. Currently 'The Terminal 2' sits at a paltry 24% positivity rating on Steam and was released August of 2014 and to not much surprise Jurassic Island seems to be heading in the same direction with a 33%.

During my first look I went searching for a tutorial to get an idea of what we were dealing with and hidden in the settings menu I found Game Tutorial" which promptly took me to a 2 minute video on YouTube. This isn't an effective way to learn how to play a game. So this didn't start off as a positive experience.

My overall experience can be boiled down into one word
date: broken. With no tutorial everything is a confusing mess. I was unsure of what to do or how to do it. I gave up on the first look when I hit a point and the game asked me to build an "Egg Mine" and it just wouldn't let me place it
recommended: anywhere. I tried to build some roads and the pathing system is impossible to direct because it was made for a touch screen
hoursPlayed: the same goes for the electric fences to keep your dinosaurs confined. Did I say dinosaurs with an 'S' as in plural
voteText: I meant dinosaur. I was only able to hatch one
helpfulPercent: because I couldn't figure out how to hatch another one
votesHelpful: or how to get more eggs.\n\nOverall
votesTotal: Jurassic Island: A Dinosaur Zoo is a broken port of a mobile game
votesFunny: if it worked there may be something here. That's not the case and it seems its bound for extinction(rimshot).\n\nFor more Indie Movie

Cons:

The controls are junk

You can't hire zoo keepers

In it's current state: 3/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eL3ntduzLWA

Jurassic Island: The Dinosaur Island is a fundamentally broken game. It's the barest sketch of a simulator with none of the details properly filled in. True, you do have dinosaurs, buildings, roads and JEEPS!. Sadly, none of these objects interact in any meaningful way, in fact, just placing them down can be a nightmare. The UI and controls are broken, there is no description of any object in the game and the tutorial is a youtube video without audio. The game's page touts, It takes only 2 minutes to build a Zoo"
date:
I spent an hour and couldn't even figure out how to open my park. I spent an hour trying to place an egg farm down...a broken game that barely promises a full Dinosaur Park experience.

PROS
-looks ok

CONS
-broken UI
-confusing mechanics
-very few things to build"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While the concept is great, playing the game is near impossible.
Trying to get things to place where you want them is a hit and miss ordeal, if you manage to get something in the right place, it will be the only item in the correct place, trying to remove a misplaced item is a worthless battle.

I do not recommend this game for anyone, you will spend more time restarting and restarting your zoo just to get htings correct.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The artistic style of this game reminds me of the Dinosaur Digs expansion for Zoo Tycoon 1. A simple, pleasing 2d display and lovely lush foliage.
In it's current form, I cannot recommend this game to people not willing to navigate clunky controls and the occasional bug or glitch, but I do see a lot of potential in this game if it can sort out the weird method of bulding fences and paths, and have a decent tutorial. I have simply had to restart several times, trying out things at random to figure out the basics of gameplay, and I still find myself going broke pretty quickly.
That being said, I find the aethetics of the game charming and would like to see it developed further, and do not regret the small amount of money spent on it. I hope to see a fully-fledged version of the game someday with decent controls and maybe more dinosaur species, as well as additional building options.
On balance, I can't recommend this title as of yet, however I will be more than willing to change my tune as the game improves.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Jurassic Island is a lot of fun, with many things going for it and it can only get better from The game is fun and has a lot of replay value.

The isometric view reminds me of Rollercoaster Tycoon (one of my favourite games of all time!). And the interface is simplistic and to-the-point, rather than clunky and overwhelming.

It features a dynamic weather cycle, befitting animations, and great terrain variety with good overall attention-to-detail. This keeps you immersed in the game. There's also a huge play area, and a sandbox vibe.

There are beta-ish elements to it though - it needs a more involving tutorial and more settings and maybe even text labels for some of the buttons.

But I would recommend it non-the-less, it's easy to pick up and fun to play!
